awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Wearable Fabric Sensor for Hydration Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase I project will provide prototype products to satisfy customer needs in prioritized wearable sensor market segments for the endurance sports market. One advantage of the proposed sensor is its similar feel to cloth fabric, a benefit in comfort and convenience to the user.  This is in contrast to current hydration monitors made of thick plastic materials requiring the use of an additional wristband or adhesive patch.  This value proposition was developed and tested based on the findings of 374 customer interviews during a spring 2017 NSF I-Corps workshop.  That study determined the commercial and product potential of a fabric sensor to monitor hydration.  In 2015 alone more than 17.1 million people finished endurance events.  According to interview data, 50% of respondents are interested in a hydration solution due to past dehydration and cramping issues. Additionally, 40% of respondents indicated interest in a technology-based solution. This group equates a target market of $342 million for a hydration monitor priced at $100 per unit, a good estimation of the total available market based on I-Corps interviews. In general, the data collected from the developed sensor could lead to better understanding of health and disease processes, including the analysis of common diabetic neurological complications, the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF), and sweat monitoring for advanced prosthetic limb applications, bedridden patients, or athlete performance tracking leading to better treatments and health outcomes for all patients.  

A monitor that analyzes the sodium concentration of a person's sweat would be able to notify them before they begin suffering from exercise-induced illnesses such as hypernatremia or hyponatermia. This early notification system would allow people to be on top of their hydration, and be able to replenish their electrolytes as needed, without overhydrating. The team has developed flexible, lightweight fabric materials that can selectively determine physiological information from sweat forming on the surface of the skin.  The technology is the first lightweight fabric sensor to provide real-time information regarding hydration levels during exercise or training. These dehydration patterns are unique and vary based on diet, weather conditions, and human physiological cycles. The ability to monitor an individual's hydration parameters is unique to the proposed sensor and gives it a competitive advantage over sweat monitors that monitor water lost or water timers that remind the athlete to drink water every 20 minutes.  Specifically, the proposed work will focus on the large-scale development of a hydration monitor, validation of the monitor during material testing and on the body in an exercise physiology laboratory, and leveraging partnerships with potential strategic partners. As athletes strive for peak performance, improper hydration can undermine their progress in both training and competitive settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The need for well-managed hydration and the monitoring of physiological parameters in real-time is not only crucial for athletes to optimize performance but to also prevent unnecessary premature deaths from occurring.  Dehydration, the excess loss of water from the body, often results in dangerous elevated sweat and blood sodium ion levels (hypernatremia).  Dehydration can cause increased cardiovascular strain, decreased blood pressure, decreased sweat rate, enhanced risk of heat stroke, severe diarrhea, and vomiting.  For some athletes, losing as little as 2% of their body mass through fluid loss can also cause a marked decrease in performance.  On the other end of the spectrum, overhydration can cause a rapid decrease in sodium ion concentration (hyponatremia) leading to confusion, nausea, vomiting, and the swelling of the extremities.  When overhydration is taken to the extreme, through inappropriate guidance, inexperience, or an unsuitable thirst stimulus, much more serious consequences occur such as swelling of the brain which can lead to loss of consciousness or even death. Although rare, overhydration has claimed the lives of endurance athletes and military recruits who were unaware of their improper hydration methods. 

 

Understanding sweat loss and calculating hydration requirements to avoid dehydration or overhydration is a significant challenge for athletes.  This is because sweat losses vary significantly from athlete to athlete both in terms of concentration of electrolytes and total volume of sweat lost.  These variations not only occur from athlete to athlete but day-to-day with changes in diet and environmental conditions.  When sweating, an individual may lose as little as ~200mg of sodium per liter or as much as ~2000 mg. This variance combined with significant differences in sweat volume lead to vastly different hydration requirements among individuals. 

 

RooSense observed, through 386 stakeholder interviews completed during Phase I of this project, that determining a proper hydration strategy is a major concern for athletes.  Therefore, RooSense has begun developing a novel product that will be the highly demanded solution to this issue. The RooSense Optimal Sweat Performance (OSP) Band is made of a sodium sensing material that is composed of a flexible, lightweight nonwoven fabric which can selectively determine physiological information from sweat forming on the surface of the skin.  A major advantage of this sensor is its nylon sensing material, which feels similar to cloth fabric, a benefit in comfort and convenience the user would demand.  This is in contrast to current hydration monitors made of thick plastic materials requiring the user to wear an additional rigid wristband or adhesive patch. 

 

The STTR Phase I project produced scaled-up nonwoven fabric sensing materials.  The nonwoven fabric sensing material was produced using industrial-scale electrospinning techniques on purchased pilot-plant scale electrospinning equipment. The equipment was selected as it was previously proven as a successful platform for another electrospinning technology start-up company (Akron Ascent Innovations) to scale their pilot-plant materials to a full-scale roll-to-roll industrial electrospinning process with toll manufacturers.  Scale-up took the electrospinning capabilities from a 3?x 18.85? mat to a 10? x 12.57? mat, an increase of 2.22-fold.

 

The nonwoven fabric sensors produced during this work maintained or improved sensor response and mechanical properties, compared to the sensor materials produced at the lab-scale. Functionalization of the nonwoven fabric showed a statistically significant increase in strength, while maintaining elasticity.  Mechanical testing carried out during the Phase I project proves that the RooSense nonwoven sensing materials can be integrated directly into clothing and gear that athletes are already wearing, a benefit of comfort and convenience to the end user that is not available with competitive technologies. The sample stress-strain curves show there is a clear enforcement effect due to the addition of nanotubes when comparing neat nonwoven nylon (solid) to the nonwoven fabric sensing material (dashed), without a significant decrease in elongation at break. Additionally, the nonwoven fabric sensing materials maintain sensor response after 20-25 controlled stretches.

 

Initial on-body testing with the nonwoven fabric sensor was performed on 22 subjects.  The prototype was placed on the subject?s back.  Results were compared to sweat collected using a piece of sterile gauze secured to the subject and analyzed using a Precision Hydration Sweat Analyzer.  The results demonstrated a high degree of correlation (actual vs predicted r-squared value of 0.87) for subjects with sweat sodium concentrations below 60 mM and indicate that the sensors can accurately determine sodium concentrations in human sweat. 

 

Phase I data has demonstrated the baseline metrics for successful scale-up and highlighted the robustness and accuracy of the sensing material during initial on-body testing. The success of this work paves the way for future work.
